chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Eye treatment
chapter.summary: Covers the management of people receiving corticosteroid eye preparations. Although corticosteroid eye preparations are initiated in secondary care, treatment may be continued and monitored in primary care following specialist agreement.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: What should I know about the initiation of corticosteroid eye preparations?
subChapters.htmlStringContent: • Treatment with corticosteroid eye preparations should always be initiated in secondary care by a specialist. However, treatment may be continued and monitored in primary care following a specialist management plan.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
This recommendation is based on information in the British National Formulary (BNF) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020].

  • Corticosteroid eye preparations should be used only under specialist supervision, as there are potential complications associated with their use:
    • An undiagnosed red eye may be due to herpes simplex virus, and the use of corticosteroid eye preparations may worsen the condition, leading to corneal ulceration and possible loss of vision. The same risks may be seen with bacterial, fungal, and amoebic infections.
    • Susceptible people may develop corticosteroid-induced glaucoma and/or cataract following the use of corticosteroid eye preparations.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What contraindications and cautions are associated with corticosteroid eye preparations?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Treatment with corticosteroid eye preparations should always be initiated in secondary care by a specialist. However, treatment may be continued and monitored in primary care following a specialist management plan.

  • Corticosteroid eye preparations should be avoided in people with:
    • Bacterial, viral, fungal tuberculous, or purulent eye conditions.
    • Herpetic keratitis. 
    • Glaucoma. 
    • Perforation, ulceration, or injury. 
    • Soft contact lenses — lenses should be removed before instillation of drops, and not worn during the period of treatment. 
  • Prescribe corticosteroid eye preparations with caution to people with:
    • A personal or family history of diabetes.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the manufacturers' summaries of product characteristics for Dexafree unit dose drops [ABPI, 2018a] and prednisolone eye drops [ABPI, 2019e], and the British National Formulary (BNF) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Can I prescribe corticosteroid eye treatments to a woman who is pregnant or breastfeeding?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Pregnancy
    • Corticosteroid eye preparations can be used in pregnancy. 
  • Breastfeeding
    • ​​​​​​​Corticosteroid eye preparations can be used in women who are breastfeeding.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Pregnancy
    • While data on systemic absorption of individual eye preparations are lacking, it is unlikely that ocular administration will be associated with an increased risk of fetal toxicity if the dose does not exceed that of systemic regimes [UKTIS, 2016c]. 
      • Systemic corticosteroids use in pregnancy has been associated with an increased risk of cleft palate and impaired fetal growth in animal models, but these outcomes have not been conclusively associated with human use. Maternal use of ocular preparations is not expected to be associated with these risks. 
    • The manufacturers' summaries of product characteristics state that there is inadequate data to determine the safety of corticosteroid eye preparations in pregnancy [ABPI, 2018a; ABPI, 2019e]. 
      • With systemic use of corticosteroids at higher doses, intrauterine growth inhibition and inhibition of the function of the adrenal cortex have been reported, but these effects have not been reported for ocular use [ABPI, 2018a].
      • Topical administration of corticosteroids to pregnant animals can cause abnormalities of fetal development including cleft palate and intrauterine growth retardation, and there may be a very small risk of such effects in the human fetus [ABPI, 2019e].
    • The UKTIS monograph on oral corticosteroids states that currently available data do not suggest that first trimester exposure to systemic corticosteroids in pregnancy increases the overall risk of congenital abnormalities, such as cleft lip/palate [UKTIS, 2016b]. 

  • Breastfeeding [SPS, 2016c]
    • Corticosteroid preparations for ophthalmic use have limited systemic absorption in the mother, and pose negligible risk to a breastfed infant. Systemic absorption from eye drops can be minimized by restricting passage into tear ducts immediately after administration.
    • There is no published evidence of safety or milk levels for any of the listed ophthalmic corticosteroids.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the adverse effects of corticosteroid eye preparations?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Local adverse effects
    • Corneal ulceration — can occur in people with ocular herpes simplex, so corticosteroid eye preparations should be avoided in such cases.
    • Increased intraocular pressure —​​​​​​​ this may lead to optic nerve damage. Ensure the person is screened regularly for ocular hypertension and glaucoma.
    • Cataract formation and thinning of the cornea and sclera —​​​​​​​ if the person is receiving long term corticosteroid eye preparations, refer them to the community optometrist to screen for cataract formation.
    • Blurring of vision  —​​​​​​​ this is transient and clears within minutes.
      • If blurring persists or there are other visual disturbances, consider for referral to an ophthalmologist for evaluation of possible causes that may include cataract, glaucoma, or rare diseases such as central serous chorioretinopathy. 
    • Increased susceptibility to bacterial, viral, and fungal eye infections.
    • Other adverse effects include chorioretinopathy, mydriasis, ptosis, epithelial punctate keratitis, corneal or scleral malaria, and corticosteroid-induced uveitis (on cessation of treatment). 
  • Systemic adverse effects — these occur rarely, are much less likely to occur than with oral corticosteroids, and are associated with high doses prescribed for prolonged periods. 
  • Systemic adverse effects include:  
    • Adrenal suppression — for signs and symptoms of adrenal suppression, see the section on Adrenal insufficiency in the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - oral.
    • Cushing's syndrome.
    • Visual disturbance, central serous chorioretinopathy, cataract, glaucoma.
      • If a person presents with symptoms such as blurred vision or other visual disturbances, consider referral to an ophthalmologist for evaluation. 
  • For more information on the systematic adverse effects of corticosteroids, see the section on Adverse effects in the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - oral.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the manufacturers' summaries of product characteristics for Dexafree unit dose drops [ABPI, 2018a], prednisolone eye drops [ABPI, 2019e], and betamethasone eye ointment [ABPI, 2018b]; the British National Formulary (BNF) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020]; and the drug reference compendium Martindale: the complete drug reference [Brayfield, 2020].

  • During ophthalmic use of corticosteroids about one-third of people will develop raised intraocular pressure, usually within a few weeks of treatment with potent corticosteroids, or within months with weaker ones [Brayfield, 2020].
  • A Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) Drug Saftey update advises that there is a rare risk of central serous chorioretinopathy with local as well as systemic administration of corticosteroids [MHRA, 2017]. 
    • People should be advised to report any blurred vision or other visual disturbances during corticosteroid treatment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What information and advice should I give to a person receiving corticosteroid eye preparations?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Advise the person that:
    • They may experience transient blurred vision after instillation of the eye drops. They should not drive or operate heavy machinery until their vision is clear.
    • Corticosteroid eye preparations should not be used while wearing soft contact lenses.
  • Advise the person on the correct technique to apply the drops:
    • Wash and dry hands.
    • Do not breathe on or touch the dropper nozzle.
    • Tilt the head back.
    • Gently pull lower eyelid downwards and outwards.
    • Place drops in the gap between the lid and eye (squeeze bottle very gently if necessary).
    • Blink a few times to spread out the drops.
    • Repeat for the other eye if needed.
  • Advise the person on the best technique to apply ointment: 
    • Wash and dry hands.
    • Tilt the head backwards.
    • Pull down the lower lid.
    • Look up and squeeze approximately 0.5 cm of ointment below the lower lid. 
    • Take care not to touch the eye with the end of the tube. 
    • Close the eyes.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the British National Formulary (BNF) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020], the Moorfields Eye Hospital patient information leaflet Corticosteroid eye drops/ointments (steroids) [Moorfields, 2017], and the manufacturers' patient information leaflets for Betnesol drops [ABPI, 2018c] and betamethasone eye ointment [ABPI, 2018d].
